Line 105: Line 105:
==Reactions==
==Reactions==
  +   +
===Domestic===
[[File:Obama Tucson Shooting Speech Cropped.jpg|thumb|left|[[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] speaking in response to the shooting]]
[[File:Obama Tucson Shooting Speech Cropped.jpg|thumb|left|[[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] speaking in response to the shooting]]
  +
[[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] called the shooting an "unspeakable tragedy," adding that "such a senseless and terrible act of violence has no place in a free society."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2011/01/08/presidents-statement-attack-arizona|title=The President's Statement on the Attack in Arizona|date=2011-01-08|work=Whitehouse.gov|accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref> Arizona Governor [[Jan Brewer]] said, "My thoughts and prayers are with Congresswoman Giffords and her family, the Congresswoman's staff and their families, as well as the other victims of this senseless and cruel violence."<ref name=azreaction>{{cite web||url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/2011/01/08/20110108arizona-congresswoman-gabrielle-giffords-shot-reaction08-ON.html|title=Arizona Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords shot: reaction|publisher=Azcentral.com|date=2011-01-08|accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref> House Speaker [[John Boehner]] said, "An attack on one who serves is an attack on all who serve. Acts and threats of violence against public officials have no place in our society... This is a sad day for our country."<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://speaker.house.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=219343|title=Boehner Condemns Attack on Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords|publisher=Speaker.house.gov||accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref> [[Chief Justice of the United States|Chief Justice]] [[John Roberts]] issued a statement noting, "we in the judiciary have suffered the terrible loss of one of our own", with the death of Chief Judge John Roll.<ref name="FOX_News_Insider">{{cite news|title=Statement from Chief Justice Roberts on Death of Judge Roll|work=FOX News Insider|format=[[XHTML]]|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=January 8, 2011|url=http://www.foxnewsinsider.com/2011/01/08/statement-from-chief-justice-roberts-on-death-of-judge-roll/|accessdate=2011-01-10}}</ref> President Obama will travel to Tucson to attend a memorial ceremony on January 12, 2011.<ref name="SVHerald-20110110-visit" />
[[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] called the shooting an "unspeakable tragedy," adding that "such a senseless and terrible act of violence has no place in a free society."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2011/01/08/presidents-statement-attack-arizona|title=The President's Statement on the Attack in Arizona|date=2011-01-08|work=Whitehouse.gov|accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref> Arizona Governor [[Jan Brewer]] said, "My thoughts and prayers are with Congresswoman Giffords and her family, the Congresswoman's staff and their families, as well as the other victims of this senseless and cruel violence."<ref name=azreaction>{{cite web||url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/2011/01/08/20110108arizona-congresswoman-gabrielle-giffords-shot-reaction08-ON.html|title=Arizona Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords shot: reaction|publisher=Azcentral.com|date=2011-01-08|accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref> House Speaker [[John Boehner]] said, "An attack on one who serves is an attack on all who serve. Acts and threats of violence against public officials have no place in our society... This is a sad day for our country."<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://speaker.house.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=219343|title=Boehner Condemns Attack on Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords|publisher=Speaker.house.gov||accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref> [[Chief Justice of the United States|Chief Justice]] [[John Roberts]] issued a statement noting, "we in the judiciary have suffered the terrible loss of one of our own", with the death of Chief Judge John Roll.<ref name="FOX_News_Insider">{{cite news|title=Statement from Chief Justice Roberts on Death of Judge Roll|work=FOX News Insider|format=[[XHTML]]|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=January 8, 2011|url=http://www.foxnewsinsider.com/2011/01/08/statement-from-chief-justice-roberts-on-death-of-judge-roll/|accessdate=2011-01-10}}</ref> President Obama will travel to Tucson to attend a memorial ceremony on January 12, 2011.<ref name="SVHerald-20110110-visit" />
â
Other politicians from across the United States, outside Arizona, and from foreign countries spoke publicly regarding the shooting, including Arizona's [[United States Senate|United States Senators]] [[Jon Kyl]]<ref name="Bizjournal">{{cite web|author=Mike Sunnucks|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/news/2011/01/08/arizona-federal-leaders-speak-out.html|title=Arizona, federal leaders speak out on shootings|work=Phoenix Business Journal|accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref> and [[John McCain]],<ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/08/AR2011010802826.html|title=McCain: Shooting a 'terrible, terrible' tragedy|work=The Washington Post|date=|accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref> House Majority Leader [[Eric Cantor]], House Minority Leader [[Nancy Pelosi]];<ref name="BBC_121144057">{{cite news|title=In quotes: Reaction to Arizona shooting|work=[[BBC News Online]]|date=2011-01-09|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12144057|accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref> Rep. [[Jeff Flake]] (R-AZ), Rep. [[Paul Gosar]] (R-AZ), Rep. [[Raul M. Grijalva]] (D-AZ), Rep. [[David Schweikert]] (R-AZ), Senate Minority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]], Arizona Attorney General [[Tom Horne]], [[Mayor of Phoenix|Phoenix Mayor]] [[Phil Gordon (politician)|Phil Gordon]], [[Janet Napolitano]];<ref name=azreaction/> Rep. [[Charlie Gonzalez]] (D-TX), former Rep. [[Ciro Rodriguez]] (D-TX),<ref name="foxsanantonio1">{{cite news|first=Christina|last=Coleman|url=http://www.foxsanantonio.com/newsroom/top_stories/videos/vid_4607.shtml|title=Local Reaction to Tucson Shooting|work=[[KABB]]|accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref> Rep. [[Henry Cuellar]] (D-TX),<ref name="foxsanantonio1"/><ref name="BBC_121144057"/> Arizona Republican Party Chairman Randy Pullen and Arizona Secretary of State [[Ken Bennett]].<ref name=azreaction/> Former [[Governor of Alaska|Alaska Governor]] and 2008 [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Vice President of the United States|vice-presidential]] nominee [[Sarah Palin]] offered "sincere condolences".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kspr.com/sns-ap-congresswomanshot-palin,0,5115428.story|title=Palin offers condolences to Giffords family|newspaper=[[KSPR]]|publisher=Perkin Media, LLC|date=2011-01-08|accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref> [[Fidel Castro]] condemned the shooting as "atrocious", "absurd" and "unjustifiable" while Foreign Affairs Minister [[Lawrence Cannon]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Ottawa offers condolences to 'valued friend' after Arizona shooting|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|location=Canada|date=2011-01-09|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/ottawa-offers-condolences-to-valued-friend-after-arizona-shooting/article1863058/|accessdate=2011-01-10}}</ref> of [[Canada]], [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British Prime Minister]] [[David Cameron]], and [[Prime Minister of Spain]] [[JosÃ© Luis RodrÃ­guez Zapatero]] offered condolences.<ref name="BBC_121144057"/><ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/01/09/fidel-castro-condemns-attack-u-s-congresswoman/|title=Fidel Castro Condemns Attack on U .S. Congresswoman|work=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=2010-02-01|accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.metronews.ca/toronto/world/article/738349--fidel-castro-condemns-attack-on-giffords|title=Fidel Castro condemns attack on Giffords|publisher=Metronews.ca|author=Paul Haven|agency=Associated Press|date=January 09, 2011|accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Cuba's Fidel Castro condemns attack on US congresswoman Giffords as "atrocious"|url=http://www.thetelegram.com/News/Canada%20-%20World/Arts/1969-12-31/article-2101883/Cubas-Fidel-Castro-condemns-attack-on-US-congresswoman-Giffords-as-atrocious/1|agency=The Canadian Press|newspaper=The Telegram|publisher=Transcontinental|location=St. John's, Newfoundland|date=2011-01-09|accessdate=2011-01-09|quote=Fidel Castro has denounced as "atrocious" a shooting attack on a U.S. lawmaker that left six people dead and the legislator in critical condition.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yucatan.com.mx/20110109/nota-11/59809-expresa-rodriguez-zapatero-a-obama-su-solidaridad-tras-atentado.htm |title=Expresa RodrÃ­guez Zapatero a Obama su solidaridad tras atentado |publisher=Yucatan.com.mx |date= |accessdate=2011-01-11}}</ref> The [[2011 BCS National Championship Game]] held in [[Glendale, Arizona]] on January 10, 2011 held a pregame moment of silence in honor of the victims.<ref>{{cite news|author=– Mon Jan 10, 8:52 pm ET |url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110111/ap_on_sp_co_ne/fbc_t25_bcs_congresswoman_shot |title=BCS game holds moment of silence before start - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-11}}</ref>
+
Other politicians from across the United States, outside Arizona, and from foreign countries spoke publicly regarding the shooting, including Arizona's [[United States Senate|United States Senators]] [[Jon Kyl]]<ref name="Bizjournal">{{cite web|author=Mike Sunnucks|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/news/2011/01/08/arizona-federal-leaders-speak-out.html|title=Arizona, federal leaders speak out on shootings|work=Phoenix Business Journal|accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref> and [[John McCain]],<ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/08/AR2011010802826.html|title=McCain: Shooting a 'terrible, terrible' tragedy|work=The Washington Post|date=|accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref> House Majority Leader [[Eric Cantor]], House Minority Leader [[Nancy Pelosi]];<ref name="BBC_121144057">{{cite news|title=In quotes: Reaction to Arizona shooting|work=[[BBC News Online]]|date=2011-01-09|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12144057|accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref> Rep. [[Jeff Flake]] (R-AZ), Rep. [[Paul Gosar]] (R-AZ), Rep. [[Raul M. Grijalva]] (D-AZ), Rep. [[David Schweikert]] (R-AZ), Senate Minority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]], Arizona Attorney General [[Tom Horne]], [[Mayor of Phoenix|Phoenix Mayor]] [[Phil Gordon (politician)|Phil Gordon]], [[Janet Napolitano]];<ref name=azreaction/> Rep. [[Charlie Gonzalez]] (D-TX), former Rep. [[Ciro Rodriguez]] (D-TX),<ref name="foxsanantonio1">{{cite news|first=Christina|last=Coleman|url=http://www.foxsanantonio.com/newsroom/top_stories/videos/vid_4607.shtml|title=Local Reaction to Tucson Shooting|work=[[KABB]]|accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref> Rep. [[Henry Cuellar]] (D-TX),<ref name="foxsanantonio1"/><ref name="BBC_121144057"/> Arizona Republican Party Chairman Randy Pullen and Arizona Secretary of State [[Ken Bennett]].<ref name=azreaction/> Former [[Governor of Alaska|Alaska Governor]] and 2008 [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Vice President of the United States|vice-presidential]] nominee [[Sarah Palin]] offered "sincere condolences".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kspr.com/sns-ap-congresswomanshot-palin,0,5115428.story|title=Palin offers condolences to Giffords family|newspaper=[[KSPR]]|publisher=Perkin Media, LLC|date=2011-01-08|accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref>
  +   +
===International community===
  +   +
[[Fidel Castro]] condemned the shooting as "atrocious", "absurd" and "unjustifiable" while Foreign Affairs Minister [[Lawrence Cannon]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Ottawa offers condolences to 'valued friend' after Arizona shooting|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|location=Canada|date=2011-01-09|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/ottawa-offers-condolences-to-valued-friend-after-arizona-shooting/article1863058/|accessdate=2011-01-10}}</ref> of [[Canada]], [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British Prime Minister]] [[David Cameron]], and [[Prime Minister of Spain]] [[JosÃ© Luis RodrÃ­guez Zapatero]] offered condolences.<ref name="BBC_121144057"/><ref>{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/01/09/fidel-castro-condemns-attack-u-s-congresswoman/|title=Fidel Castro Condemns Attack on U .S. Congresswoman|work=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=2010-02-01|accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.metronews.ca/toronto/world/article/738349--fidel-castro-condemns-attack-on-giffords|title=Fidel Castro condemns attack on Giffords|publisher=Metronews.ca|author=Paul Haven|agency=Associated Press|date=January 09, 2011|accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Cuba's Fidel Castro condemns attack on US congresswoman Giffords as "atrocious"|url=http://www.thetelegram.com/News/Canada%20-%20World/Arts/1969-12-31/article-2101883/Cubas-Fidel-Castro-condemns-attack-on-US-congresswoman-Giffords-as-atrocious/1|agency=The Canadian Press|newspaper=The Telegram|publisher=Transcontinental|location=St. John's, Newfoundland|date=2011-01-09|accessdate=2011-01-09|quote=Fidel Castro has denounced as "atrocious" a shooting attack on a U.S. lawmaker that left six people dead and the legislator in critical condition.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yucatan.com.mx/20110109/nota-11/59809-expresa-rodriguez-zapatero-a-obama-su-solidaridad-tras-atentado.htm |title=Expresa RodrÃ­guez Zapatero a Obama su solidaridad tras atentado |publisher=Yucatan.com.mx |date= |accessdate=2011-01-11}}</ref> The [[2011 BCS National Championship Game]] held in [[Glendale, Arizona]] on January 10, 2011 held a pregame moment of silence in honor of the victims.<ref>{{cite news|author=– Mon Jan 10, 8:52 pm ET |url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110111/ap_on_sp_co_ne/fbc_t25_bcs_congresswoman_shot |title=BCS game holds moment of silence before start - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-11}}</ref>
â
===Political debate===
+
==Political debate==
{{POVsection|date=January 2011}}
{{POVsection|date=January 2011}}
''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that the shooting raised concerns that American politics had become too heated.<ref name="NYTimes-20110110-spotlight">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/10/us/10arizona.html?_r=1&src=twt&twt=nytimes|title=Shooting Casts a Harsh Spotlight on Arizonaâs Unique Politics|first=Jennifer|last=Steinhauer|work=The New York Times|date=January 9, 2011|accessdate=2011-01-10}}</ref> Giffords had previously expressed concerns about a website created by the [[SarahPAC|Sarah Palin Action Committee]] that used icons resembling [[reticle|gun scope crosshairs]] on a U.S. map to denote targeted congressional seats for the 2010 [[United States midterm election|midterm elections]], of which Giffords' was one. The map, together with a note entitled "Don't Get Demoralized! Get Organized! Take Back the 20!" was also posted on Palin's [[Facebook]] page on March 23, 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.articlesurfing.org/politics_and_government/sarah_palin_facebook_reconstructed.html |title=Screenshot of Sarah Palin's Facebook Page Prior to Removal of Her "Cross Hairs" Map |work= |accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref> The picture was removed from the site by Palin's team following the shootings, who stated the markers were never intended as crosshairs, but as [[survey marker|surveyor's marks]].<ref name="nyt-vitriol">{{cite news|title=Bloodshed Puts New Focus on Vitriol in Politics|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/09/us/politics/09capital.html|author=Carl Hulse|coauthors=Kate Zernike|accessdate=2011-01-08|newspaper=The New York Times|date=2011-01-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/09/advisor-linking-palin-to-shootings-appalling/|title=Adviser: Linking Palin to shootings 'appalling'|author=Mark Preston|work=CNN|date=January 9, 2011|accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref>
''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that the shooting raised concerns that American politics had become too heated.<ref name="NYTimes-20110110-spotlight">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/10/us/10arizona.html?_r=1&src=twt&twt=nytimes|title=Shooting Casts a Harsh Spotlight on Arizonaâs Unique Politics|first=Jennifer|last=Steinhauer|work=The New York Times|date=January 9, 2011|accessdate=2011-01-10}}</ref> Giffords had previously expressed concerns about a website created by the [[SarahPAC|Sarah Palin Action Committee]] that used icons resembling [[reticle|gun scope crosshairs]] on a U.S. map to denote targeted congressional seats for the 2010 [[United States midterm election|midterm elections]], of which Giffords' was one. The map, together with a note entitled "Don't Get Demoralized! Get Organized! Take Back the 20!" was also posted on Palin's [[Facebook]] page on March 23, 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.articlesurfing.org/politics_and_government/sarah_palin_facebook_reconstructed.html |title=Screenshot of Sarah Palin's Facebook Page Prior to Removal of Her "Cross Hairs" Map |work= |accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref> The picture was removed from the site by Palin's team following the shootings, who stated the markers were never intended as crosshairs, but as [[survey marker|surveyor's marks]].<ref name="nyt-vitriol">{{cite news|title=Bloodshed Puts New Focus on Vitriol in Politics|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/09/us/politics/09capital.html|author=Carl Hulse|coauthors=Kate Zernike|accessdate=2011-01-08|newspaper=The New York Times|date=2011-01-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/09/advisor-linking-palin-to-shootings-appalling/|title=Adviser: Linking Palin to shootings 'appalling'|author=Mark Preston|work=CNN|date=January 9, 2011|accessdate=2011-01-09}}</ref>
